metadata.title: Generation of DD - Reactions in a Ferroelectric KD2PO. Single Crystal During Transition Through Curie Point (Te = 220 K)

body_text.text: In their Letter to Nature, B. Naranjo et al [1] presented a desktop neutron generator based on deuteron beam ionized and accelerated up to 100 keV by electric field arising from the spontaneous polarization of ferra/pyroelectric LiTaQ, crystal at a low pressure deuterium gas adsorption. The results of this work are appeared to be solid with respect to both experimental and theoretical aspects of 2.45 MeV DD-neutron production. However, a certain early history exists on a deuteron fusion driven by a strong erystalline electric field.
: we demonstrate our results on DD-reaction (neutrons and tritium) in DKDP during transition throug 3 MeV proton emission using CR-39 trae

The amplitude-differential spectra of neutron emission are presented in Fig. 1. As seen, the sum of spectra for DKDP exposed at the neutron detector during ferroelectric phase transition near 220 K are in good agreement with Cf-252 amplitude spectrum.

This picture unambiguously confirms presence of neutron emission during transition through Curie point.
The neutron counts are consistent with spontaneous polarization occurring in DKDP crystals during feroelectric phase transition as it is shown in Fig. 2.

Tritium concentration in DKDP has been measured by liquid scintillation technique. The sample were 100 times cycled through Curie point in a glass capsule. After the cycling the crystals, glass and gas atmosphere of the ampule
 $1 0^{9}$

Thus, there is no significant difference between D-eaction channels when 3.0 MeV proton and neutron yields are compared. That is why, the $7$ order enhancement of tritium channel compared to neutron and proton yield observed during DKDP cyeling through Curie point cannot be explained by conventional DD-reaction.
